thread.title: Asylum seeker on Nauru holds grave concerns for the health of her child and husband
thread.title_full: Asylum seeker on Nauru holds grave concerns for the health of her child and husband

author: ABC Radio National
title: Asylum seeker on Nauru holds grave concerns for the health of her child and husband
text:
Image: Nauru asylum seeker camp (ABC News) 
In recent weeks, the Turnbull Government has been forced to defend the standard of health care available on Nauru, after a number of pregnant asylum seekers demanded to be taken to Australia for the safe delivery of their babies. 
Immigration Minister Peter Dutton says the Australian Government 'won't be taken for mugs and blackmailed' into allowing people to come to Australia for medical attention, when it has spent $26 million upgrading clinical facilities on Nauru. 
But despite the multi-million dollar upgrades, RN Breakfast has heard directly from one asylum seeker who says the health care available on the island is inadequate, and she's desperately worried about the health of her baby and her husband. 
Abhaya* says her 9-month-old daughter—who was born in Darwin and transferred back to Nauru when she was 5 months old—has been sick for two months, suffering from diarrhoea and high temperatures. 
This week, the baby's health deteriorated when she became unconscious after swallowing a millipede. 
In a distressed state, Abhaya, who is a trained nurse, told RN Breakfast from Nauru that the clinic didn't do enough for her daughter. She was particularly upset that no doctor was made available. 
Abhaya is also angry at the lack of mental health support for her husband Veejay*, who is in a poor mental state, which she says was brought on from his treatment by immigration security in Australia. 
Not being on Nauru, it is difficult to see for ourselves the reality of Abhaya's circumstances. RN Breakfast has verified her account as far as possible with people who have dealt with her and her family both in Australia and on Nauru. 
Abhaya joins Fran Kelly on RN Breakfast from Nauru. 
*All names of asylum seekers have been changed for legal reasons.
